section.title: The Role of the Federal Reserve
section.p: In modern economies, central banks play an important role in maintaining a national monetary system. In the United States, the functions of a central bank are handled by the Federal Reserve System (established in 1913). In this section, we will examine the role of central banks in general, and the Federal Reserve in particular.

As with , the Study Note includes a wealth of empirical facts that could be tested. We do not claim that this section is comprehensive in that respect. We recommend you supplement this activity with a careful reading of the study note.
We begin with central banks. Central banks have two main functions -- to facilitate payment systems and to act as a lender of last resort to commercial banks.

introduction.p: Which function of a central bank is represented by the following scenarios?

task.p: A commercial bank needs to borrow funds overnight to satisfy demands from savings account holders.

A customer pays for their coffee with a debit card. The customer banks with McCord Bank. The coffee house banks with Morejon Bank. Funds are transferred from McCord Bank's reserve account to Morejon Bank, and funds from McCord Bank are transferred back into their reserve account.

introduction.p: Central banks require every bank in their system to maintain a specific amount of funds in it called the bank's reserve requirement. The account is the bank's reserve.

task.p: Come up with at least one reason why banks would have reserve requirements.
The amount of the reserve requirement can change over time. Which of the following are factors that help determine reserve requirements for McCord Bank?

li.p: The importance of McCord Bank in the overall payment system.
The Central Bank's need to satisfy demands of individuals (people) who hold savings accounts with them.
The salary of McCord Bank's executive officers.
The volume of transactions performed by McCord Bank.

section.p: A bank's reserve can be used for overnight transfer to facilitate payments, but the bank has to make sure their reserve requirement continues to be met.

statement.p: Suppose a central bank facilitates payments through transfers of reserve requirements. Put the following steps of a payment series in chronological order.

li.p: Morejon Bank makes a demand for payment from McCord Bank.
Russel Jackson uses his debit card from McCord Bank to buy groceries from his favorite grocery Washington D.C. grocery store, Stevie's (the store banks with Morejon Bank).
McCord Bank debits Russel Jackson'account and transfers the funds to their reserve at the central bank.
The Federal Reserve transfers funds from the McCord reserve to the Morejon reserve.
McCord Bank transmits a notice to make a payment to Morejon Bank.
The funds are credited to Stevie's account at Morejon Bank.
The funds are transferred to Morejon Bank from their reserve at the central bank.

section.p: In their role as lenders of last resort, central banks use reserve accounts as a source of funds. In addition, some central banks (but not all) are authorized to issue currency. In addition to supporting their role as lenders of last resort, the authority for actions such as issuing currency allows the central bank to set monetary policy by controlling the supply of money and setting interest rates. Monetary policy has an impact on inflation and unemployment. In the United States, although the Federal Reserve sets monetary policy, they are not authorized to issue currency. Their tools are less direct (as we will see).

introduction.p: Suppose the statute authorizing the creation of a central bank in the Republic of Actuariastan reads as follows:
The Central Bank of Actuariastan has the following powers:

li.p: to establish, maintain, and update the mechanisms for transfers of payments between Registered Banks in the Republic of Actuariastan,
to hold deposits and make payments on behalf of the Republic of Actuariastan,
to facilitate transfers between the Central Bank of Actuariastan and foreign banks,
to lend funds to Registered Banks in the Republic of Actuariastan and to set the interest rate for loans to Registered Banks,
to issue Treasury Bonds, and
to repurchase Treasury Bonds.

task.p: Suppose the Central Bank of Actuariastan is concerned that the interest rate is too high and wants to reduce the interest rate. Which of the following strategies are authorized and will reduce the interest rate? Select all that apply.

li.p: Issue more currency into the country.
Withdraw currency from the country.
Issue Treasury Bonds.
Purchase Treasury Bonds.
Increase the interest rate charged for loans to other banks.
Reduce the interest rate charged to loans for other banks.

task.p: The Central Bank is only authorized to manage mechanisms for transfers of payments between Actuariastan banks. How does the statute envision transactions involving foreign banks will be facilitated?

section.p: In the United States, the central bank functions are handled by the Federal Reserve System. The Federal Reserve System is made up of 12 regional banks together with a committee called the Federal Open Markets Committee (FOMC). The regional banks and the FOMC are governed by the Board of Governors.

The Federal Reserve is authorized to take monetary action to help control inflation and unemployment, but they are not authorized to issue currency. Instead, they set interest rate targets through market activities. The FOMC determines a target rate and the regional banks buy and sell T-Bills in the open market in order to try to achieve that rate.

statement.p: Sketch a diagram illustrating the components of the U.S. Federal Reserve System.

section.p: To be more specific, the Federal Reserve is able to manage two different interest rates. The federal funds rate is the interest rates banks charge one another for overnight loans. Overnight loans will be necessary when reserves fall below their requirement. The FOMC sets federal funds rate targets to be achieved through T-Bill purchases and sales by the regional banks.

The other rate, directly controlled by the Federal Reserve, is the rate at which commercial banks borrow directly from the Federal Reserve. This is called the discount rate and comes from the discount window. Banks prefer to borrow from other banks as it shows that they are creditworthy.

statement.p: On a given day, the discount rate is 3.65%, the prime rate is 3.55%, the LIBOR is 3.30%, the federal funds rate is 3.25%, and the federal funds target rate is 3.20%.

On the same day, Bank XYZ's reserve balance held at the Federal Reserve is lower than the reserve requirement, and Bank XYZ needs to borrow from those member institutions of the Federal Reserve who have excess funds in their reserve. Let x be the rate at which Bank XYZ borrows these excess funds.

introduction.p: For each of the following scenarios in the United States, determine which rate is involved.

task.p: A bank facing a shortage and unable to borrow from its peers has to borrow from the Federal Reserve.
Due to a concern about a stock market bubble, the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City sells bonds in order to increase interest rates.
The Federal Open Market Committee sets targets in order to decrease interest rates in order to increase capital investment.
The Federal Reserve charges a higher rate for loans it makes to other banks.
Morejon Bank borrows funds overnight from McCord Bank in order to satisfy depositor demands for the day.

section.p: We conclude by considering how setting the federal funds rate target impacts interest rates in the market.

introduction.p: Suppose the FOMC takes action that increases the federal funds rate.

task.p: What does this action do to the cost of falling below reserve requirements for a bank like McCord Bank?
How would a bank like McCord Bank alter its lending decisions in response?
How would this impact the supply and demand of loanable funds, and what is the consequence for the market interest rate?

statement.p: Suppose the FOMC takes action that decreases the federal funds rate. Following similar logic, describe how this impacts market interest rates.
Summarize the role central banks play in an economy, and what this looks like in the United States.
